taskbody.context: Use this procedure to start cluster services.

step.cmd: Use the virtual hostname or virtual IP address of the high-availability cluster to log in to the primary master node .
In a separate terminal session, log in to the secondary master node .

substep.cmd: On the primary node, start DRBD.
substep.stepresult: The following example output is expected: Moving the internal meta data to its proper location Internal drbd meta data successfully moved.

substep.cmd: On the secondary node, start DRBD.
substep.stepresult: The output of this command should match the output on the primary node.

substep.cmd: On both nodes, confirm that the DRBD device for the serviced thin pool is larger.

step.cmd: On the primary node, wait for disks to synchronize.
step.stepresult: Do not proceed until the status of all devices is UpToDate/UpToDate.

step.cmd: On the primary node, start cluster services for the distributed file system.
Confirm the identity of the primary node.
On the primary node, resize the volume group that contains the serviced thin pool.

substep.cmd: Identify the volume group that contains the serviced thin pool.
substep.stepresult: Typically, the logical volume is serviced-pool and the containing volume group is serviced.

substep.cmd: Display information about the volume group.
substep.stepxmp: Replace Volume-Group with the name of the volume group identified in the previous substep: vgdisplay Volume-Group

substep.cmd: Identify the DRBD disk associated with the serviced thin pool.
substep.info: Typically, the serviced thin pool device is associated with /dev/drbd2. To verify the configuration in your environment, review /etc/drbd.d/serviced-dfs.res.

substep.stepxmp: Replace DRBD-Device with the DRBD device associated with the serviced thin pool: pvresize DRBD-Device

substep.cmd: Display information about the volume group.
substep.stepxmp: Replace Volume-Group with the name of the volume group identified in the previous substep: vgdisplay Volume-Group
substep.stepresult: The size of the volume group should be larger.

step.cmd: On the primary node, resize the serviced thin pool.

substep.cmd: Start the serviced group cluster services.
Add space to the data storage area of the serviced thin pool.
substep.stepxmp:
In the following command:
Replace Total-Size with the sum of the existing device size plus the space to add to the device, in gigabytes. Include the units identifier, G.
Replace Volume-Group with the name of the LVM volume group identified in the previous step.
Replace Logical-Volume with the name of the logical volume identified in the previous step.
lvextend -L+Total-SizeG Volume-Group/Logical-Volume

substep.cmd: Display information about LVM logical volumes on the host.
substep.stepresult: The result should show the larger size of the logical volume.

step.cmd: On the primary node, start the storage resource.

substep.cmd: Confirm that the service started correctly.

step.cmd: Increase the size of the application tenant volume, if desired.

substep.cmd: Display the device mapper name of the serviced thin pool.
Increase the size of the tenant device.
substep.stepxmp:
In the following command:
Replace Device-Mapper-Name with the device mapper name of the thin pool.
Replace Tenant-ID with the identifier of the tenant device.
Replace Total-Size with the sum of the existing device size plus the space to add to the device, in gigabytes. Include the units identifier, G.
serviced-storage resize -d /opt/serviced/var/volumes \ -o dm.thinpooldev=Device-Mapper-Name Tenant-ID Total-SizeG
